title: what brexit backstop plan theresa may eu irish border latest
story: Heres our guide to the plan and what it means for Northern Ireland and its border with the Republic of Ireland.The backstop plan is essentially a safety netthere is no Brexit trade deal.It would avoid a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland.The backstop will see Britain remain in the customs union for as long as necessary until an alternative way of keeping the border open is found.It would ensure that no tarfs, quotas, rules of origin or customs processes would be applied to UK-EU trade.At the same time the UK would be able to strike free trade agreements with other countries.On November , EU leaders approved an agreement on the UKs withdrawal from the EU.MPs will now be asked to approve the agreement when it comes before the House of Commons next week.Attorney General Geoffrey Cox has been ordered to publish all the legal advice hes given Mrs May on her proposed deal - but has¬†only handed over a summary¬†instead.It concluded the proposed backstop would stop Britain making trade deals around the world in a separate legal document.Addressing the issue of the backstop - which will keep Britain in the customs uniontheres no other way to protect the Irish border - the Attorney General said: There is no unilateral right for either party to terminate this arrangement.This means thatno superseding agreement can be reached within the implementation period, the protocol would be activated and in international law would subsist, evennegotiations had broken down.How likely that is to happen is a political question, to which the answer will no doubt depend partly on the extent to which it is in either partys interests to remain indefinitely within its arrangements.We are indefinitely committing to itit came into force. There is no point in the Government trying to hide that fact.The Democratic Unionist Party has vowed to oppose any new checks on goods passing between Great Britain and Northern Ireland.Irelands Foreign Minister, Simon Coveney, said that EU Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier indicated that the European Union will allow extra time for talks about the border.Mr Coveney said he was frustrated and disappointed that it was going to take more time than people had hoped.

title: worlds weirdest homes
story: His unique house is one of six featured in a new documentary, The Worlds Weirdest Homes.The Channel  show sees architect and presenter Charlie Luxton travel to far-flung destinations such as Arizona in the US, Dubai and Rio de Janiero to meet people who have chosen to live somewhere unusual.From the entrepreneur who lives on a version of Noahs Ark - complete with wooden beasts - to the scientists living on an exact replica of Mars, Sun Online takes a look at some of the most bonkers places people call home.Name: The Private ZooLocation: DubaiWho lives there ¬†Rashed BelhasaThe son of billionaire UAE construction tycoon,¬†Sa¬†Ahmed¬†Belhasa, Rashed is used to flaunting his luxurious lestyle online, posting several videos from the room he has just to house his growing trainer collection.But nothing has drawn attention as much as his impressive private zoo in the grounds of his dads opulently-decorated mega mansion.Rasheds collection of living beasts includes¬†lions, tigers, panthers, leopards, cheetahs, giraffes and bears, all with pets ostentatiously named after his favourite brands - Versace, Armani and Dior.The zoo has attracted a number of celebrities, from singer Mariah Carey to Cristiano Ronaldo, Jackie Chan and Floyd Mayweather.Rashed says the younger animals get to come inside for snuggles, and claims he is the only  year old in the world with his own zoo.However, he has come under fire from people who have branded the zoo cruel, but says his father inspired him to help animals after he started taking in neglected creatures from other private zoos.We dont make profit from it, says Rashed. When I went to Kenya I saw lions dying because they only ate once a month. Here they eat every single day.Name: Mars Desert Research StationLocation: UtahWho lives there ¬†A group of eight scientistsWith plans to eventually form a colony on Mars - and Elon Musk saying he wants to put people on the red planet by , it seems important that humans are well prepared.Thats where the Mars Desert Research Station comes in. Built in the early noughties, it is a¬†replica space station where scientists live exactly asit were Mars,¬† .The base is located¬†in the remote desert of Utah near the small town of Hanksville.The area looks very like Mars due to the barren red rock, mountains and sand, as well as similar rock types to those found on the Red Planet.The tiny base, where eight scientists live on a rotating basis, is smaller than an average London one-bed flat and features bunk beds in tiny closet-style rooms.They have just one toilet to share, and are only able to eat freeze-dried food asthey are in Space.People tell us that we are running around playing dress-up in a spacesuit, but its not like that at all, says Dr Shannon Rupert, who heads up the project.Name: Noahs ArkLocation:¬†The NetherlandsWho lives there ¬†Dutch entrepreneur Aad PetersIn ,¬†Johan Huibers, a Dutch Christian fundamentalist, decided to build a replica of Noahs Ark as he wanted to¬†save humanity from sin after having a vision.Painstakingly crafted, the replica is  metres long, . metres wide,  metres high and made of steel, pine and cedar.In , Huibers sold the ark for ¬£, to Aad Peters, an entrepreneur who wanted to sail the vessel around¬†Northern Europe with live animals on board including camels and elephants - two-by-two of course.However, Aad was forced to concede three months later that unlike in the Biblical Story, an ark is not a suitable home for animals, so he took them off board.Theres not a lot of space...its like camping on sea, says Aad. If the wind blows it and youre lying shivering under five blankets you wonder am I stupid  but it is what it is. If you choose to do something you have to do it.Last year, he collided with a few other boats during a storm, and its also caught fire.At present, it is currently anchored by a car park and is a museum filled with wooden animals, but Aad says he plans to sail the high seas once it is repaired.Name: Sandcastle HouseLocation:¬†Rio de Janeiro, BrazilWho lives there ¬†Marcio¬†Mizael MatoliasSea views are desired by many of us - and Rio de Janeiro resident¬†Marcio¬†Mizael Matolia has found a nty way to get a prime spot without the hefty price tag.For the past  years, the self-styled King of the Castle, who is adorned with a plastic crown, has lived inside his sandcastle.He says the seat outside is his pulpit, where he sits for people to come and pay respect to him and donate money to him to help him live in his strange structure.The impressive creation, in an exclusive neighbourhood surrounded by luxury flats worth millions, has  turrets, which he made by hand using sand, drtwood and water.However, though it looks great from the outside, Marcios living space is a six metre square room held up by a wooden frame.I dug a hole, then put some wood underneath so it didnt sink, says Marcio. Its a real work of architecture and engineering.Unsurprisingly, there are some setbacks with this set up. He doesnt have amenities such as a toilet so he uses public loos when he needs a poo and wees in the sea.In the rainy season his castle washes away, meaning it needs constant repairs. It takes between six and eight hours to make a couple of towers, so he can find this incredibly frustrating.Name: Freedom CoveLocation:¬†British Columbia, CanadaWho lives there ¬†Wayne Adams and Catherine KingThe pair have lived on the secluded farm, which floats on the ocean and weighs  tonnes - the same as a ship - for  years.The home, which is anchored to shore using lines like a giant spiders web, boasts huge areas of garden, a multi-coloured house, art gallery, dance floor and even a lighthouse.Its here that Catherine grows fruit and vegetables while Wayne, who built all of Freedom Cove himself, creates additions to their home in his workshop. The pair also fish from a hole in the floor.However, the house has regularly suffered from severe storm damage as its built in an area known for high winds.The pair say the roof has blown off several times, and ious sections of it have been completely destroyed at times.Name:¬†Falcons NestLocation:¬†Prescott, ArizonaWho lives there  Tarot readers¬†Ernst and SrishtiErnst and Srishti often ran around the countryside near their home in Arizona, dreaming of owning the very peculiar building theyd go past.Falcons Nest towers at over ft high and with  floors, is the tallest single-family home on the planet. It was out of the couples price range at ¬£.million- but an accident last year changed everything.The sporty pair were out on one of their regular runs when they were run over by a pick-up truck.Their insurance payout meant they would be in a position to buy it and they jumped at the chance.With stunning views over Arizona, the¬†main living area has , square feet of space all the way up on the sixth floor.However, it takes a lot of maintenance: two days to clean all  windows using a special brush as they are so high up, and several people in the town complained about the building, calling it an eyesore.And the couple also admit their unusual abode attracts a lot of attention, with people pulling up outside in the cars to take photos on a regular basis.Our home is a tourist attraction, they tell Charlie Luxton.Thats certainly something you can say for all these other unusual buildings too.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: no10 need more time to tell whether full on no deal preparation is necessary
story: This was the moment at which the principal purpose of government was meant to sht to getting this country ready for leaving the EU, regardless of whether there was deal or not.The Department For Exiting The EU wanted November  but No argued that a more vague deadline of late November  early December was better.They thought that this would give more time to tell whether full-on ‚Äúno-deal‚Äù preparation was necessary or not.But now No‚Ää is indicating that it wants to hold off until after the meaningful vote in Parliament on December .This is deeply irresponsible.Those inside the machine estimate that it would take four months of intense preparations to get this country into a place where it could make no deal manageable.So, by waiting until after the meaningful vote, the Government is denying itself valuable time.I am told that new Brexit Secretary Steve Barclay, who will update Cabinet on no-deal preparedness on Tuesday, is frustrated at the foot- dragging by No‚Ää. A growing number of other ministers share this concern.Theresa May, of course doesn‚Äôt want no deal. She wants Parliament to approve the deal she has negotiated.But, right now, it is hard to see how it passes.The DUP have said they won‚Äôt vote for it, denying the Government its majority, and  Tory MPs have declared they will vote against it ‚Äî ¬≠suggesting the Government is on course for a heavy defeat.‚ÄúIt is increasingly dficult to see what rescues this,‚Äù said one of those charged with getting it through.Given thatthe withdrawal agreement is defeated and nothing is put in its place then this country leaves the EU without a deal, it is foolish not to massively intensy planning for that outcome.At every point since the ¬≠referendum, the Government has put off crucial decisions on no-deal planning.This has weakened the UK‚Äôs negotiating position and means the UK is now ill-prepared for what Mrs May admits is one of the three most likely outcomes.The situation is so serious that one member of the Privy Council told me this week that the military should be drafted in to help.This former Cabinet minister‚Äôs argument was that only the military had the logistical know-how to ensure that ¬≠critical supplies make it all around the country in time.May still hasn‚Äôt given up on getting the withdrawal agreement through Parliament.But there is little sign of a decisive sht in her favour.Cabinet ministers are still talking in terms of the scale of defeat, rather than of victory.The expectation among ¬≠ministers is thatMay loses the vote by  or less, she will seek clarication on the ¬≠backstop and then try and bring it back to the Commons.But, as one leading member of the Cabinet warns, May will have to move fast.If she loses the meaningful vote she ‚Äúcould face the  letters and a vote of no confidence in short order‚Äù.THE Housing Secretary, James Brokenshire, has scored a ¬≠signicant victory over the Chancellor.Brokenshire wanted to reduce the maximum deposit that renters would have to pay from six weeks‚Äô rent to five.The idea was that this would be fairer on tenants who must find the money for the deposit up front. But Philip Hammond objected.The Chancellor wrote to Cabinet colleagues that ‚ÄúI cannot agree to the proposed concession to lower the deposit cap from six weeks‚Äô rent to five weeks‚Äô rent.‚ÄúSix weeks‚Äô rent was already placing landlords at risk of uncovered loss for damage to property, as well as risk of loss of rent.‚ÄúThis bill was always a high- risk measure. A cap of six weeks‚Äô rent was already a major concession and I believe we have to hold the line at this level.‚ÄùHowever, Hammond‚Äôs objections have not carried the day. The Government will now back reducing the deposit cap to five weeks for all but the most expensive properties.One of the Tories‚Äô biggest problems is being seen as the landlords‚Äô party. Hammond himself declares rental income of more than ¬£,.In , the Tories were more popular than Labour among those who rented in the private sector.But at the last election, ¬≠Labour had a -point lead over the Tories among private renters.The Tories won‚Äôt win these voters back by dragging their feet on measures that make le easier for tenants.SENIOR Labour figures are plotting a route to an early General Election that doesn‚Äôt involve having to get two thirds of the Commons to vote for it.One close ally of Jeremy Corbyn in the Shadow Cabinet tells me that the plan would be to defeat the Government in a confidence motionthe ¬≠Government loses the meaningful vote.The idea would be to persuade the DUP to join with Labour and the other opposition parties in voting against the Government. This would result in a narrow defeat for Theresa May.At that point, the Fixed Term Parliament Act allows  days for the Commons to approve an alternative government.In these circumstances, no government could be approved ‚Äì the DUP wouldn‚Äôt actively put ¬≠Corbyn into No‚Ää while no Tory leader could be elected in that time who would meet the DUP‚Äôs requirements on the backstop.The result of all this would be that with ¬≠Parliament deadlocked, there would have to be another General Election.How realistic the Labour front bench consider this scenario is crucial. For there is mounting tension in the Shadow Cabinet about whether or not Labour should formally back a second referendum.At the moment, Labour‚Äôs policy is to push for a General Election above all .But this week, John McDonnell ‚Äì the Shadow Chancellor ‚Äì admitted that securing a General Election was ‚Äúvery dficult‚Äù so the party may well back a second referendum instead.TORY party donors have received a letter from party HQ defending the deal that Theresa May has ¬≠negotiated.Attached to the letter is a rather revealing document setting out why ‚Äúthe backstop is needed in all scenarios‚Äù.It lists four future scenarios for UK EU relations ‚Äì a Canada-style trade deal, EEA membership, a UK EU customs union and the UK being in both the customs union and the single market.Three of these four options would be deemed unacceptable by most Brexiteer MPs.WHEN the then Culture Secretary Matt Hancock scrapped Leveson , the next stage of the inquiry into the Press, critics claimed that either Parliament or the courts would force him into a U-turn.But the key votes in the Commons were won, and this week the courts rejected the appeal for a judicial review of the decision.With Labour having gone cold on Section , which would have forced newspapers to sign up to a state regulator or pay both sides‚Äô costs in disputes, the freedom of the Press remains.The challenge now is never to allow it to be threatened in this way again.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: celebrating freedom european union
story: It is a crying shame that nobody in Government has put their heart into a vision of a truly global Britain. The PM is in Buenos Aires rightly extolling our virtues to world leaders, but it‚Äôs hard to shake the feeling that her Cabinet are afraid that Britain cannot make it on its own. That weakness has been exploited time after time by EU negotiators.If only they shared the faith of those who voted for a brighter future.The scandalous lack of planning for a clean break, as James Forsyth makes clear on this very page, is a result of the Government only ever looking for pitfalls ‚Äî rather than grabbing the opportunities that are so obviously out there for a reinvigorated Britain.It‚Äôs not too late. If the PM loses the crunch vote in Parliament, we must step up preparations to leave without a deal by several notches.And that might well see Brussels bureaucrats, for all their harsh words, coming back to the negotiating table.The disgraced tycoon Max Mosley, via his family trust, has pledged to keep funding this so-called independent body for years to come, as he continues his vendetta against the free Press.Labour donor Mr Mosley is no fan of the papers, and not just for exposing his extra-curricular activities. The media also uncovered his racist past, including pamphlets warning: ‚ÄúColoured immigration threatens your children‚Äôs health.‚ÄùWhen that bile came to light, the Labour Party promised not to take another penny from him. But he‚Äôs spent years bankrolling their Deputy Leader Tom Watson‚Äôs office to the tune of hundreds of thousands of pounds.Isn‚Äôt it time the cash was handed back, Mr Watson Ms Bibi, a Pakistani Catholic, was acquitted last month of blasphemy charges ‚Äî a charge which had left her on death row. Whilst she‚Äôs in hiding, hardline Islamists have been parading around the country‚Äôs streets with images of her in a noose. It is clear she will never be safe in Pakistan.We should be proud of the fact that Britain is open to those of all religions and none, and give her a home here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sick of being bullied by eu
story: Even‚Äújust getting on with it‚Äù means becoming a non- voting member of the EU Even‚Äújust getting on with it‚Äù means Brexit in name only Even‚Äújust getting on with it‚Äù means our country ‚Äî not invaded for , years ‚Äî becomes a colony of Brussels No thanks, Nanny May!It is not Brexit that the ¬≠British people are bored with.The British people are sick of being BULLIED.Bullied by politicians like that eternal glumbucket Philip Hammond, a Chancellor of the Exchequer with the demeanour of a coffin chaser, who has never ever accepted the result of the largest poll in British history.Bullied by Bank of England boss Mark Carney, who warns that daring No Deal will cause unemployment to soar, house prices to tumble and inflation to come over all giddy.And bullied, yes, by our PM ‚Äî a decent woman trying to do her duty under impossible ¬≠circumstances, but who has never believed in her heart that Brexit was anything other than an exercise in damage limitation.And, above all, we are sick of being bullied by Brussels.From the first to the last, our ‚Äúfriends and partners‚Äù in Brussels have treated this country with sneering disrespect.Even when they come from countries where they would be speaking ¬≠Germanit wasn‚Äôt for our fathers and grandfathers.That‚Äôs what we are really bored with, Theresa ‚Äî the bully boys in Brussels.The EU are acting like they have won.And who can blame them May‚Äôs lousy stinking deal would leave us shackled to the European Union but with no say on how that incompetent, job-shredding empire is run.May‚Äôs deal would cripple our ability to strike trade deals around the world.And for the privilege of ¬≠kissing the EU‚Äôs boots, the British taxpayer gets to pay ¬£billion.No wonder our ‚Äúfriends‚Äù in the EU are gloating!Truly, with Theresa‚Äôs deal looking like it has little chance of crawling past Parliament, this would be a great time for our EU ‚Äúfriends‚Äù to keep their mouths firmly shut.But they just can‚Äôt stop gloating.¬≠President Emmanuel Macron, that numpty ¬≠Napoleon, says the threat of keeping the UK trapped in the customs union forever gives France ‚Äúleverage‚Äù ‚Äî that is, a big stick to wave when France seeks access to British fishing waters.The thuggish Martin ¬≠Selmayr, the EU‚Äôs chief Brit-hating bureaucrat, gloats ‚Äúthe power is with us.But who do you think you are kidding, Mister Selmayr,you think this old country‚Äôs done I just can‚Äôt believe that this proud, free nation will bend the knee and capitulate to Brussels.I can‚Äôt believe we will ¬≠cravenly accept Nanny May‚Äôs warning that we must become an EU colony, or it will be very, very bad indeed.I have no idea how many of the dire predictions currently doing the rounds are true.I have no ideawe will end up with no deal, the ¬≠Norway option, the Canada option or Comrade Corbyn‚Äôs preference ‚Äî the Venezuela option.But I do know this is still a great country.As I write these words, ¬≠people are risking their lives on the cruel waters of the English Channel in the hope of a better le.And NONE of them are heading to France. NONE of them are laying their lives on the line to get inside the European Union.Are you worried about our future  Me too.I am afraid that the ¬≠uncertainty will drag on for years. I am afraid the ¬≠uncertainty will have a ¬≠negative impact on everything ‚Äî investment, employment and something as simple as our quality of le.Project Fear turned out to be Project Fibs ‚Äî but nobody can truly know what is going to happen in every possible ¬≠scenario.But one thing is absolutely certain. Mrs May, for all her decent and noble efforts, all her hard work, is offering us a future where we would be worse off than we are today.And nothing terries me more than being a colony of Brussels.For all the uncertainties around all of the alternatives, Mrs May‚Äôs deal throws away freedoms that better men than me fought and died for.Nobody has the moral right to give away our sovereignty. Nobody.Our Prime Minister has shown courage and a sense of duty.But she has also ¬≠displayed pessimism and defeatism.She has tried to treat our ‚Äúfriends‚Äù in the European Union with decency and respect.All of her sense of fair play has been thrown back in her face.The likes of Herr Selmayr and Monsieur Macron are crowing that the price of Brexit is the humbling of the United Kingdom.They are bullying us.And there will be more ¬≠bullying to come ‚Äî for decades, forever ‚Äîwe do not stand up to them now.What  can you do with a bully What a cruel and bitter irony it would bethis ¬≠country surrendered to a ¬≠hostile enemy without losing a war! And what a national tragedy.What a heart breaker. What a total betrayal of all the generations who came before us.But this nation has not waved the white flag for one thousand years.Tell me ‚Äî are we really going to start now ¬†Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pictures animals speared humans kenya
story: The pictures reveal how a British-funded charity is on the front-line treating African wildle being speared and in most cases left for dead.Animals have been a frequent target of spear attacks as over¬†the past  months, and charities have encountered numerous cases of such conflict in Kenya.Just a month ago, in these pictures from The David Sheldrick Wildle Trust , an elephant was found with a spear tip embedded cm into its skull.In another shocking example, a lion was incredibly lucky to escape being blinded after a two-metre spear was stabbed into his face.Working with rangers from the Masai Mara National Park, in Kenya, the DSWT and the Kenya Wildle Serviceare constantly trying to protect and help injured animals.In both these instances, the DSWT and KWS managed to sedate and treat the animals which incredibly each escaped without having any vital organs damaged.Over the past  months, the DSWT and KWS have encountered numerous cases of human-wildle conflict resulting from their territories over-lapping.Rob Brandford, Executive Director of the Trust said the five DSWT KWS Mobile Vet Units work in five important ecosystems across Kenya.He said: ‚ÄúIn the Masai Mara, where this lion was treated, human-wildle conflictis a prevalent issue ‚Äì as it is across Kenya ‚Äì especially during the drier months when wildle leaves the national reserve and ventures into community land in search of food and water.‚ÄúWhen this happens, predators may follow them and during this time, the Vet Units are called to more human-wildle conflict cases.‚ÄúOur vets handle a wide iety of cases, though safe to say human-wildle conflict victims are on the rise.‚ÄúEver-expanding human populations mean something has to give, or be taken, and that is land formerly only utilised by wildle. This is something we are seeing worldwide, not only in Africa.‚ÄùBrandford said in the elephant case the unit treating the elephant was the DSWT KWS Tsavo Veterinary Unit, headed by KWS Vet, Dr Poghon.He explained despite the deep impact of the spear tip, the skull makeup of the huge animal helped her survive the injury.He said: ‚ÄúIf you took a cross section of an elephant‚Äôs skull it would appear like honeycomb.It is basically to reduce weight, because elephant skulls are so large, and need to be for the ears, trunk and of course tusks, they cannot be too heavy.‚ÄúThey have this sponge-like structure, and fortunately for this elephant, that is where the spear landed.‚ÄúOf course, much deeper, or further down, could have been a dferent matter, hitting an eye for example.‚ÄùBrandford added that the treatment of the elephant was a good example of persistence paying off.A lion was also on the receiving end of a spear attack a year ago, and these images show just how close it had come to death.As the lion lay on the ground sedated, a huge two-metre spear can be seen sticking out of his face just below the right eye.According to the DSWT, human-wildle conflict is one of the most pressing threats facing Africa‚Äôs wildle.

story: Avril Rowlands and her husband Christopher stuck a ft fir in their front garden after enjoying their first Christmas at their new home in .Now the tree towers above their four-bedroom detached house and the couple have to hire a cherry picker to decorate it using more than , lights.And on Sunday, the couple celebrated the monster firs th anniversary when they switched on the lights.It now illuminates the entire street where the couple live in Inkberrow, Worcs.Retired TV writer Avril, , said: The switch-on event has become an absolute institution for the village and we have hundreds of people see the tree.Weve even had tourists coming from as far as China to have their pictures taken by the tree.It is amazing to think that the tree started as a ft tall sapling which we bought for just ¬£.I remember after that first Christmas thinking to myself that I didnt want to just throw the tree out so I planted it in the front garden.It took straight away and every year its just grown taller and taller.It now takes , to light the tree, I dont look at the electricity bill until after Christmas.The couple moved to the quiet village in the summer of  after selling their home in London.And their annual switch-on event has become a local institution which raises thousands of pounds for charity.Retired BBC editor Christopher, , said: A lot of people in the village say that its the start of their Christmas.We usually raise about ¬£, a year for charity, a dferent one each year - this year all the money is going to the Midlands Air Ambulance.Over the last  years weve raised over ¬£, for charity.Were delighted the tree has spread so much happiness and raised so much money.We expect itll be for many years to come.Inkberrow is one of a handful of villages in the country which doesnt have any street lights and the tree can be seen from a mile away at night when it is lit up.A spokesman for the Forestry Commission said: This is a remarkable tree which has obviously been taken care of.Pine trees can grow to huge heights so time will only tellthis one grows any larger.

title: ofsted chief amanda spielman says schools are now being asked to do things that should be done by parents
story: Watching kids in a classroom is great fun. Most are keen and eager to learn. That‚Äôs why teaching can be a really rewarding job, but there‚Äôs no doubt it is also a tough one.Today I will be launching my annual report, which will show that, overall, schools in England are doing a good job.The vast majority of children are attending good or outstanding schools, which is as it should be. Young people get just one shot at childhood ‚Äî leaving no room for complacency.Yet in recent years it feels like more and more is being asked of schools and teachers, which could put this improvement at risk.They are being asked to do things that should be done at home by parents, as they used to be.This is making the job of schools harder. It takes up too much precious time and stops teachers from doing their actual job ‚Äî teaching.One of the most shocking examples I hear about is the growing number of children beginning their reception year still in nappies.I‚Äôve asked about this in primary schools this year, and each time I‚Äôve asked I‚Äôve been told it is a real problem.This is dficult for teachers, embarrassing for the children concerned and disruptive to their classmates.Quite simply, it is wrong. Toilet training is the parents‚Äô job. It should not be left to schools. Only in the most extreme cases should parents be excused from this most basic of parenting tasks.And this isn‚Äôt the only area that concerns me.We all know about the growing problem of childhood obesity. By the start of primary school, almost a quarter of children in England are overweight or obese. This is at the age four or five.This rises to more than a third by the time they go to secondary school.It is estimated that nearly , young people in the UK are now suffering from type  diabetes, an unpleasant disease normally only seen in people over the age of .Schools have an important role to play, teaching children about the importance of healthy eating and exercise. Kids need to get out of breath during PE.But schools can‚Äôt do it all. It is lazy for us to rely on schools to change kids‚Äô habits.And the reality is, that as Ofsted research shows, schools on their own can‚Äôt make the dference. The answer to the obesity crisis, particularly among younger children, lies in the home, and parents need to make sure their offspring eat healthily, go outside, and don‚Äôt spend all day playing on electronic devices.There is no point in teaching about healthy choices, making sure school meals are healthy or having rules about what goes into a packed lunch,for breakfast, dinner and all weekend children have a supply of junk food.One of the saddest things I‚Äôve heard about recently is cases where children have leftover fast food, cold chips or chicken nuggets, in their packed lunches the following day. With the best will in the world, schools cannot fight this single-handedly.Sadly, in some parts of our country, schools are also at the forefront of tackling a very dferent kind of risk: kne crime and gang culture.Thankfully most schools are safe, and of course they can help educate young people about the dangers of knives and how to avoid being drawn into gangs.But they cannot be expected to solve the problem alone. Preventing kne crime requires people working together ‚Äî police, youth services, health services ‚Äî to protect children and to do everything to bring those who cause harm to children to justice.However we must not forget the role of parents here either. This is about taking responsibility for your child. I accept that many families are busy and that some children have dficult and complex problems to deal with.But that doesn‚Äôt excuse parents from the basics of teaching their children right from wrong, giving them proper boundaries and security. And that means not trying to be their ‚Äúbest friend‚Äù.One answer may be to introduce more parenting classes. We know these can work and help parents who might otherwise be struggling.These shouldn‚Äôt be for schools to run, but perhaps to run in schools. Maybe now is the time to look again at the ambitions of the Le Chances strategy or the ideas behind the Sure Start programme.But parents must recognise they cannot off load their responsibilities at the school gate.Every minute we ask teachers to spend on these issues is time children aren‚Äôt learning the Rs, studying our nation‚Äôs history or the scientic forces that shape our world.I want schools to be able to do their proper job, and to let them do that, parents have got to step up.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: aerial photos reveal lockerbie plane
story: NewsAerial photos reveal Lockerbie plane wreckage lying in unforgotten Lincolnshire scrapyardAll  passengers and crew on Pan Am Flight  were killed when a bomb went off over Scotland on December , ShareCommentsByBradley JollyElaine McCahill:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsAerial photos show the wreckage of the Lockerbie plane wreckage lying forgotten in a scrap yard "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThese chilling photos capture what is believed to be the mangled wreckage of the Pan Am plane which was blown up over Lockerbie  years ago. Remains of the downed aircraft have been photographed lying in a heap at Windleys Salvage, a scrapyard in Tattershall, Lincs. Its believed the splintered metal was transferred there in eight lorry loads from an Army base at Longtown near Carlisle. Some  passengers and crew were killed when a bomb was detonated on Pan Am Flight  over Scotland on December , .   Eleven Lockerbie residents also died by falling debris in the tragedy, including two families.It remains the worst terror attack in British history. What remains of the plane has been pictured in a scrapyard, with metal wreckage visible in aerial photographs. Following the attack, Insurance firm Lloyds hired Windleys Salvage to store the majority of the scrap metal. The mid-section of the plane - where the bomb went off in the cargo - remains at the Air Accidents Investigation Branch in Farnborough, Hampshire.   Only one person has been convicted over Lockerbie, Libyan Abdelbaset al-Megrahi, who was jailed for le in . Co-accused Lamen Khala Fhimah was acquitted. Al-Megrahi died in , aged , after being freed on compassionate grounds three years earlier.Dr Swire and a number of British victims‚Äô families believe he may have been wrongly convicted.   In , the Mirror revealed a security guard at Heathrow ‚Äì where the New York-bound plane made a stop ‚Äì discovered a break in at the Pan Am baggage area on the day of the attack. This was not revealed during the trial.Libya was suspected early in the probe as former leader Muammar Gaddafi is believed to have wanted revenge for the US bombing of Tripoli in . But the finger of blame was also pointed at Iran. In July , a US Navy warship in the Persian Gulf shot down Iran Air Flight , killing  civilians, including  children. December ,  Pan Am Flight  from Frankfurt to Detroit, via London and New York, blows up over Lockerbie in Scotland. All  people on board are killed, along with  residents on the ground, including two families. November  Britain and the US accuse Libyans Abdelbaset Al-Megrahi and Al Amin Khaila Fhimah of the bombing. Libya denies involvement. January  MPs demand an inquiry after US intelligence suggests Iran was behind the bombing ‚Äì not Libya. American officials play down the report. January  Megrahi is convicted of mass murder. Fhimah is found not guilty August  UN lts sanctions on Libya after Tripoli accepts the blame and compensates families of the victims. August  Megrahi is freed after being diagnosed with prostate cancer. Returns home to Tripoli to cheering crowds. He dies in . October  Authorities say they are investigating two more suspects linked to Libya. November  The Scottish Criminal Cases Review Commission says there was no criminality in the Megrahi case.  The Lockerbie Air Disaster Fund raised pound.million, of which nearly half was spent compensating victims and the rest went on projects in the town. Libya‚Äôs regime eventually accepted responsibility for the attack and agreed in  to pay pound.billion in compensation infor the lting of international sanctions. Windleys Salvage told The Sun it could not confirm whether the remains of the plane are kept at the scrapyard.

title: make up artist reveals 25
story: NewsMake-up artist reveals ¬£ product that cured her severe acne within weeksAlice Muir, , from Edinburgh, wouldnt even let her own family see her without a full face of make-up as she was so self-conscious about her skin - but now she proudly shows off her before pictures to customersShareCommentsByRosa McMahon:,  DEC NewsAlices skin at its worst "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA make-up artist who dreaded leaving the house because of her severe acne has revealed how a pound toner transformed her skin within weeks. Alice Muir was so ashamed of her ‚Äúmountain-sized‚Äù spots that she would spend almost two hours covering them up with foundation, before events like her work Christmas party. The -year-old wouldnt even let her own family see her without a full face of make-up as she was so self-conscious. But after years of hunting for a cure - trying everything from antibiotics to expensive specialised potions - in May this year Alice, of Edinburgh, Scotland, combined a diet overhaul with a high street toner and within six weeks her skin was completely clear. Alice, who works for a luxury beauty retailer and now has a pimple-free complexion, said: ‚ÄúPeople honestly don‚Äôt believe it‚Äôs me now when I show them my ‚Äòbefore‚Äô photos.   ‚ÄúMy acne was all over my face and was bright red and sore all the time. ‚ÄúI like to show customers who are having issues with their skin, to make them see that they‚Äôre not alone and things do get better.‚Äù Alice, who is single, was battling with cystic acne - the most severe form of the spotty skin condition, which occurs when oil and dead skin cells build up deep within hair follicles, causing a rash of infected boils. Ironically, it was training for the job she loves so much that triggered her problems when, after leaving school, aged , she started studying make-up artistry at Edinburgh College - practising the looks she had been taught at home, using heavy make-up on her own face. ‚ÄúI was practising at home at least three nights a week, applying really heavy make-up, so I could then take photos and post them on my social media, to show what Id done,‚Äù she said.   ‚ÄúI‚Äôd apply foundation, concealer, powder, bronzer, blusher and highlighter, before Id even added my eye make-up.‚Äù Until then, Alice had been blessed with clear skin and, preferring a natural look, to being heavily made-up, she was often complimented on her fresh complexion. ‚ÄúPeople would ask me, ‚ÄòWhy don‚Äôt you have any spots ‚Äô. Most people of  did, but I didn‚Äôt seem to have any problems,‚Äù she said. That all changed a month into her new course, when she noticed blemishes popping up and her pores opening - making her skin more prone to break-outs. Recalling how the blemishes became bigger and angrier, she continued: ‚ÄúThey were actually under the skin, so I couldn‚Äôt pop them. They were just there, like mountains on my face. Alice was even more mortied at college, when her fellow students had to make her face up for her, and started to wear cover-up all the time.   ‚ÄúNot even my own family saw me without a full-face of make-up when the acne got really bad,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt would take me up to one-and-a-half hours every day to just put my full face on. Her doctor prescribed a series of lotions, creams and antibiotics, in a bid to improve her skin, following her cystic acne diagnosis, aged , but nothing seemed to work. ‚ÄúI realised it was the make-up I was applying on my course that had started the terrible acne, but there seemed to be nothing I could do about it,‚Äù she recalled. When she landed her current job, following her two-year course, Alice felt ashamed of her acne-covered skin when she was applying clients make-up and helping them to choose expensive skincare products. She said: ‚ÄúI was supposed to be advising people on how to care for their skin and which make-up to use, but they must have been looking at me thinking, ‚ÄòSort out your own skin before giving me advice‚Äô.   ‚ÄúNo one ever said that to me, but I was sure that was what they were thinking. The terrible thing was there was nothing I could do about it.‚Äù On a long waiting list to see a dermatologist and refusing to take the strong acne drug Roaccutane, which slows down the amount of oil your skin releases but according to the NHS can also have a serious side effect of depression, Alice felt helpless. ‚ÄúI knew I had to do something. I was desperate and felt horrendous about myself,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt want to go out and dreaded events like the work Christmas party or my graduation, as I didn‚Äôt want people looking at me. ‚ÄúI hated looking in the mirror and didn‚Äôt recognise the girl looking back at me, I felt disgusting.‚Äù So, in May this year, Alice decided to take the issue into her own hands.   After being given a sample at work of the brand REN‚Äôs Ready Steady Glow Daily AHA Tonic, Alice says she noticed a change in her skin just a week after using it. As well as using the pound skincare treatment every night, Alice also overhauled her diet, cutting down on carbohydrates and following a ‚Äòclean eating‚Äô plan, eating mainly plant-based foods. Now, six months on, Alice‚Äôs skin is beautully clear, without a pimple in sight. Before she was cured Alice had not even allowed her family to see her spotty skin barefaced, but now she is releasing her photos in a bid to raise awareness about adult and cystic acne. She said: ‚ÄúIt can happen to anyone, and it‚Äôs not because you‚Äôre not clean or you don‚Äôt wash. ‚ÄúAt the work Christmas party this year, I won‚Äôt feel ashamed of how I look. Instead, I‚Äôll feel proud of how far I‚Äôve come, and, who knows, I might even get a cheeky kiss under the mistletoe.‚Äù

Two thirds of those polled admit they often get confused about when to say ‚Äòcould‚Äô, ‚Äòshould‚Äô or ‚Äòwould‚Äô have, while a fth also don‚Äôt understand the dference between using the words ‚Äòfewer‚Äô and ‚Äòless‚Äô. ‚ÄòMe‚Äô, ‚Äòmyself‚Äô and ‚ÄòI‚Äô also causes problems for some  per cent of folk, while others are baffled about abbreviations such as i.e. and e.g. Basic punctuation can also leave some adults scratching their heads, with  per cent unable to use speech marks correctly,  per cent not really understanding where or when to place a question mark and  per cent clueless about apostrophes. But despite the results of the OnePoll study three quarters of adults think they are good at writing, and  per cent think they have a good knowledge of the English language. Gyles Brandreth added: ‚ÄúThe survey is a wake-up call.‚Äù ‚ÄúGood English matters. Proper punctuation and correct spelling are essential to good, clear, effective communication - and this survey shows things ain‚Äôt as they should be. ‚ÄúPeople are making too many spelling mistakes - with new words as much as with old ones. And in the age of the email and the tweet they are confused about punctuation. ‚ÄúTeachers need to do more to help children understand the basics. And in a post-Brexit world, our use of English matters more than ever. It‚Äôs the English language that gives us our global clout. title: uks youngest instagram influencer bagged
story: NewsUKs youngest Instagram influencer has bagged ¬£, of freebies aged ONERalphie Waplingtons mum Stacey Woodhams has banned family members from sharing pictures of the tot, in order to protect his imageShareCommentsByRosaleen Fenton:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsRalphie with his parents, Stacey and Adam, at their home in Essex "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA one-year-old baby has proved so popular as an Instagram star that he has already bagged more than pound, of freebies. Ralphie Waplington is in heavy demand from brands desperate to have him model their products. Each picture on his Instagram account - which has more than , followers - shows him without a hair out of place, and his mum has banned family members from sharing pictures of him. Mum-of-one Stacey Woodhams, who runs the account, has landed a bumper crop of freebies from sharing posts of the little boy, including his entire wardrobe, bedroom furniture and days out. And she says she‚Äôs even keen to have another baby - so the child can tap into Instagram‚Äôs huge market for newborn ‚Äòinfluencers‚Äô now that Ralphie is too old. Stacey admits that she‚Äôs received hate mail and threats from fellow mothers online and warns parents that they shouldn‚Äôt run Instagram accounts for their children unless they‚Äôre prepared for the gut-wrenching backlash.   But Ralphie can make hundreds of pounds from a single sponsored post and has a dferent pram for every day of the week, all sent to him for free, infor a photograph. Stacey, from Brentwood, Essex, who styles all his outfits and snaps photos with her smartphone, says she has landed more than pound, worth of freebies for her star child. The -year-old originally set up an Instagram account for Ralphie when he was seven days old so that their family could see him grow. But within a month, she had amassed more than , followers and now spends hours every day focusing on Ralphie‚Äôs account.   She credits the social media giant for giving her the opportunity to work from home as she earns enough from running the account alongside her own business Mummas Prints. After a slew of adoring comments on his photographs, she realised that her son could become an ‚Äòinfluencer‚Äô, opening up chances to work with brands and companies. As a family, Stacey, Ralphie, and his dad Adam Waplington, , have enjoyed free trips to theme parks, posh meals and popular tourist highlights, including Peppa Pig World. She earns a salary from his posts which she says she spends on family days out and treats for her boy. On top of his income from Instagram, the tot, who turns two in December, also earns a salary from modelling for brands including Next, which is kept separately in his own bank account.   Stacey said: ‚ÄúI‚Äôve worked really hard to achieve what we have achieved and everything I do is for Ralphie and his future. ‚ÄúIf a photo of him in a tracksuit with snot running down his face and his hair is messy gets put on social media, that is not representative of the brands we are representing. ‚ÄúIt sounds awful referring to him a brand because he is a human and a child but essentially, the name that we have created is a business. ‚ÄúAnd that‚Äôs what I‚Äôm trying to say to people when they bash me, this is a business. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not dferent to me leaving the house at am and ing at pm but instead I have a job where Ralphie reaps the rewards and I get to spend all day with my son. ‚ÄúSo our family aren‚Äôt allowed to post photos unless it‚Äôs a photo we‚Äôve already posted or a photo I‚Äôve approved. ‚ÄúAnd before I take any photographs, we‚Äôll make sure his hair is brushed. It‚Äôs about giving him a bit of dignity, after all I wouldn‚Äôt post a photo of me not at my best!   ‚ÄúOne lady had a go at me saying I was too busy taking photos of him posing as a model. ‚ÄúWell, he is a model. He‚Äôs represented by an agency, he does a lot of modelling and he‚Äôs worked with some really big names. ‚ÄúSo yes, I do take photos where he looks lovely because he is!‚Äù Stacey makes sure she plans ahead so photos of Ralphie are strategically shared when they‚Äôre likely to receive the most attention. She says this includes posting photos at am when fellow frazzled parents are likely to be scrolling through their phone whilst their children keep them awake. Overall, Ralphie‚Äôs received more than  free outfits, as well as free bedroom furniture, free designer toys and eight prams sent by baby brands. And Stacey and Adam have received free meals including a lavish afternoon tea at Fortnum  Mason, treatments at salons and gts including a free set of luggage and a free kingsize mattress.   Stacey said: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been invited to days out at themes parks, we‚Äôve been offered hotel stays, a furniture company gave us all of Ralphie‚Äôs bedroom furniture. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been sent handbags, suitcases, Hugo Boss designer clothes. We got a luggage set for all of us. ‚ÄúRalphie is really lucky. All of his clothing comes from Forever Sewing, they sponsor his wardrobe, and we love working with small businesses. But his profile didnt become a viral sensation overnight, as Stacey says she spent months ensuring that regular daily uploads saw her gain followers. She says she works hard to portray the daily struggles of motherhood rather than presenting a le that many cannot relate too. However, the effort was worth it, as the mum says Ralphie earns up to pound per sponsored post. But while most fans praise the handsome toddler and are quick to praise Stacey for her hard work, others aren‚Äôt so quick to big the tot‚Äôs Instagram page up. In the past, she‚Äôs received messages accusing of neglecting her son in favour of taking photographs of him. Stacey said: ‚ÄòI definitely put on a front so when someone calls you a bad mum, it really does hurt me.   ‚ÄúI just think thatsomeone was doing what I do but wasn‚Äôt in the right frame of mind, I wonder what these Instagram trolls could do. ‚ÄúI think people don‚Äôt realise the nastiness of what they say and how it could affect someone.‚Äù Although she admits to having spent a lot of time on her phone, she insists that Ralphie never notices. She says: ‚ÄúIt only take a split second to take a photograph and I do all the editing when he‚Äôs asleep or Adam is home. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a lot of prep work. You can only photograph himhe‚Äôs in a good mood and he‚Äôs happy to play. ‚ÄúI never force him to sit still, I just snap him in the moment so he‚Äôs none the wiser and it‚Äôs just like any other mum capturing a photo.   ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs at that age where we can explain to him what we‚Äôre doing. ‚ÄúObviously its stressful because you have a brief from some brands to get it from a certain angle and just one shot to do it. ‚ÄúOnce you set it up,he messes it all up, then you won‚Äôt get a good image. So we really do have to work as a team. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve got Adam running around like a performing monkey distracting him but Ralphie just laughs and thinks its funny. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve visited some great places and he‚Äôs actually having a lot of fun but for me, it‚Äôs like being at work, ‚ÄúSo I‚Äôm filming, editing and doing Instagram stories on my phone and probably looking like I‚Äôm having the worst time. ‚ÄúSo it‚Äôs not all it seems.‚Äù And as Ralphie‚Äôs following increases, Stacey says she understands why parents might criticise her. She said: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre exposing Ralphie to a le that‚Äôs he‚Äôs not had a choice in. He‚Äôs not been able to say ‚Äòyes mummy‚Äô, I want to do this.   ‚ÄòUltimately, we try and understand it from people with a negative opinion. ‚ÄúHow we see it is, yes, there‚Äôs a lot of views and opinions on what we do and how we could be putting him in danger. ‚ÄúBut at the same time, I know that everything we post is filtered and we want to portray him as the little boy having fun that he is. ‚ÄúI can see why people would think we are using him as a tool for potentially making a name for our family, and as a form of income but this isn‚Äôt the case. ‚ÄúBut I post to inspire other people that you can achieve anything. I am an ordinary girl from a really ordinary background. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve had ups and downs in my lives but I know you can achieve anythingyou work hard at it. ‚ÄúI feel really grateful to be given the opportunities that we have been given.‚Äù And as Ralphie gets older, brands are becoming more intrigued by the rest of the family, including Adam, who works in the wholesale restaurant business.   The pair recently set up an Instagram account focused on him and hope that he may be able to quit his full-time job in the future. Adam said: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm still really new to the whole thing. ‚ÄúWe found that opportunities would come up that involved dads so we thought it was a no-brainerI got involved.‚Äù But Stacey says that she still spends a lot of time contacting brands to suggest they work with her. She said: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like any business, You have to go out and get it. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd say seventy per cent of the work we obtain is through me reaching out to source it, and thirty per cent where we get contacted directly.‚Äù Now the -year-old has begun running workshops for fellow parents on how to use social media and promote their businesses or their own family influencer accounts. She said: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm so passionate about what I do ‚ÄúI think Instagram is quite misunderstood but it can be a really positive place to share your story. In the near future, the family hope to have another child who they can also share on Instagram. Stacey said: ‚ÄúSome of the companies that got in touch when Ralphie was  or  weeks old, we still are in contact with. ‚ÄúUnfortunately a lot of products only make things for newborns so we‚Äôre longing for baby two now so we can carry on!‚Äù

title: who edith cavell google doodle
story: NewsWho was Edith Cavell  Facts and quotes as Google celebrates heroic WW nurseWhile working as a nurse in Belgium during the First World War, Edith Cavell was helping Allied soldiers escape the German Occupation. She is honoured by a Google Doodle on her rd birthday.ShareCommentsByDaisy Naylor:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsThe latest Google Doodle honours nurse Edith Cavell, who was born  years ago on this day "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe latest Google Doodle honours a British nurse who risked her own le to help Allied soldiers escape from Occupied Belgium during the First World War. Edith Cavell was born in the village of Swardeston, near Norwich, on  December . The eldest of four children, she was educated at Norwich High School for Girls, and then she found work as a governess. She didnt become a nurse until she was -years-old, and inspired by the experience of caring for her seriously ill father Frederick. After successfully nursing him back to health Edith applied to train as a nurse probationer at the Royal London Hospital in Whitechapel. She went on to have an illustrious medical career both in hospitals and as a private travelling nurse. Edith worked in Shoreditch, Kings Cross and Manchester before moving to Brussels in .  There she was appointed matron of Belgiums first nursing college, and within just a few years she was an expert training nurse for three hospitals,  schools and  nurseries across the country. She also founded a medical journal, LInfirmiere, in .Outbreak of WW Edith Cavell was visiting her family in England when WW broke out in . She immediately ed to Brussels, stating that I cant stop while there are lives to be saved. Ediths school was transformed into a Red Cross hospital, and she would treat casualties of the war regardless of their nationality, or what side of the conflict they were fighting on. She was also covertly working with the Belgian resistance. While Brussels was occupied by German forces, Edith was sheltering French and British soldiers and helping them escape to the neighboring Netherlands, which was neutral territory. Its believed that she helped over  men to safety, many of whom wrote to thank her once they reached home.  Unfortunately, Ediths activities didnt escape the attention of the German authorities, and she was eventually arrested and charged with treason. She was prosecuted in a court-martial, found guilty, and sentenced to death. This provoked international outrage, and there were cries for Edith to be granted a reprieve. People argued that she should be spared death, especially given that she saved so many lives - both Allied and German - through her pioneering work as a war nurse. These cries fell on deaf ears, however, and Edith was executed by firing squad at the Tir National on  October . She was just -years-old.  Legacy After the war, Ediths body was brought back to England and laid to rest at Norwich Cathedral, where a graveside service is held annually on the anniversary of her death. There are memorials dedicated to Edith around the world, and she is commemorated by the Church of Englands calendar for saints on  October every year. In , the Nations Fund for Nurses was launched in Ediths honour, and charity Cavell Nurses Trust supports nurses, midwes and HCAs who are experiencing hardhsips. Ediths legacy of compassion, bravery and heroism lives on, and is remembered to this day. Edith Cavell facts When she was growing up, Edith had a passion for painting. She was also an extraordinarily gted French speaker. Before she moved to Brussels to work as a nurse, Edith had actually already lived there. As a young woman, she spent five years working as a governess in the Belgian capital.Edith won a medal in  for her work with typhoid patients. She also cared for those with cancer, appendicitis and eye ailments.When Edith was working to smuggle Allied soldiers out of Belgium, she was helped by Prince Reginald and Princess Marie of Croy - members of the Belian aristocracy.It is believed that Edith was betrayed when a Belgian spy discovered a secret tunnel underneath her hospital.After her death, Edith became a popular figure in British propaganda, encouraging people to join the military.In , Ediths legacy was celebrated on a commemorative pound coin. The inscription reads, She faced them gentle and bold.  Edith Cavell quotes Patriotism is not enough, I must have no hatred or bitterness to anyone. I have no fear nor shrinking I have seen death so often that it is not strange or fearful to me. Someday, somehow, I am going to do something useful, something for people. They are, most of them, so helpless, so hurt and so unhappy.

story: A Dundee hairdresser has launched the city‚Äôs first ‚Äúhair bank‚Äù to provide wigs to those in need without them costing the Earth.Karen Ward, , owner of Bladez hair and beauty salon on Lawers Drive, started collecting pre-loved wigs about two months ago and has already amassed .She opened the salon eight years ago ‚Äì and has since become a consultant contact on hair loss with NHS Tayside.However, while providing wigs for referred patients with conditions such as alopecia, she started receiving wigs from the families of former owners who had passed away.Karen said: ‚ÄúMy mum Avril had alopecia, so I‚Äôve always been around the idea of hair loss.‚ÄúI know how much wigs can costyou‚Äôre not getting them on prescription.‚ÄúA really good wig can cost you about ¬£, which is out of reach for a lot of people.‚ÄùThe nearest existing hair bank in Scotland is in Edinburgh.This made Karen, from Emmock Woods, wondershe could provide a more local service ‚Äì and took to sterilising the donated wigs herself.Wigs can be purchased from the Dundee Hair Bank at a cut price, with the proceeds being donated to causes such as Maggie‚Äôs, Alopecia Tayside and Ninewells Hospital.Karen added: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm selling most of the wigs for about ¬£ and the maximum so far was ¬£ for a really long one that needed a lot of care.‚ÄúThe hair bank also gives people who wear wigs an opportunity to buy wigs for occasions like weddings.‚ÄúMost people will go out and get their hair done for events like that.‚ÄúIf you have hair loss that shouldn‚Äôt be any dferent for you.‚ÄùSince launching the Dundee Hair Bank online earlier this week, Karen has received messages of support from all over the world.She said that she had found the experience ‚Äúoverwhelming‚Äù, adding: ‚ÄúI lost my mum to cancer, sadly ‚Äì but I know that she would‚Äôve loved me doing this.‚ÄùFor more information on Dundee Hair Bank and the wigs that are available, visit www.facebook dundeehairbank.

title: Big plans to revamp city centre street
story: A BOLD vision to transform a key area in Inverness city centre has been unveiled with local residents and businesses being invited to have their say.The project is set to shape the future of Academy Street and also complement a multimillion-pound upgrade of the rail station and revamp of the Victorian Market.Options include widening pavements, reducing traffic speeds and introducing streetscape features to improve the look and feel of the city centre.The aim is to make it easier and safer for pedestrians and cyclists to access the station from Academy Street, Falcon Square, and the bus station at Farraline Park Rose Street.The seven-week consultation has been launched by HiTrans, the regional transport partnership for the Highlands and Islands.It is working with Highland Council, Sustrans Scotland and city centre organisations on the Accessing Inverness project following a successful application for funding to Sustrans Community Links Programme.Civic and business leaders are urging the public to get involved with events due to be held in the Eastgate Centre or the Victorian Market, or via the councils website from next week.Inverness Provost Helen Carmichael outlined the signicance of the proposals."This is a hugely important project in our ambitious plans to regenerate the city centre," she said."What a boost the city will get through the upgrade of the railway station and greatly improved links from Falcon Square, Academy Street and Farraline Park."The provost was part of a delegation from Inverness which visited the market town of Altrincham near Manchester which was decimated by recession but has bounced back to become a bustling money spinner.The delegation also saw how the community had tackled challenges of improving the safety and accessibility in a busy town centre with a transport exchange."I would urge the public to play their part by giving us their thoughts on the options we have presented," Provost Carmichael said.Views should be submitted by January  to https:highland-consult.objective portal* Let us know what you think: email newsdesk@spp-group or take part in our Big Vote .Tuesday  Dec  : AM

title: Boost to Inverness Elgin rail service
story: Improvements to the passenger rail service between Inverness and Elginare tostart rollingthis month, in time for Christmas travellers.Nine additional services have been announced providing close to an hourly service for much of the day between the Highland capital and the Moray capital with Nairn and Forres in between.The new services will provide more than , additional seats each day, providing  per cent more capacity which promises to be a boon for commuters and shoppers in both directions.And ScotRail promise journey times of around  minutes between Elgin and Inverness making travel times ldquoconsiderably faster than car.ScotRail also says that the new services offer the opportunity to build a  for better integration with existing local bus services, for example between Elgin and Lossiemouth.The new Inverness to Elgin trains which start rolling on December , are part of a massive package of rail improvements also coming to other parts of Scotland from next month.They include the fastest journey time between Edinburgh Waverley and Glasgow Queen Street of  minutes, and rail journeys in key locations that will soon be faster than car journeys.Mike Smith, manager of Inverness Bid, said: ldquoAccess to Inverness is crucial to the city and the Highlands so we welcome this.ldquoHowever, we also need improvements to other rail services to the city both for visitors and also for people who are coming to work here.ScotRail said: ldquoWersquore building the best railway Scotland has ever had. The investment we are making now will transform Scotlandrsquos railway for years to come.ldquoWersquore introducing brand new electric trains, recreating an InterCity network with high-speed trains, and upgrading many existing trains. This will mean more seats, faster journeys, and even better services.Tuesday  Dec  : AM

title: Businesses give backing to city centre project plans
story: BUSINESS leader Peter Strachan believes the plans to transform a key part of Inverness city centre will make a big dference.Proposals were unveiled last week that aim to make it easier and safer for pedestrians and cyclists in Academy Street and the surrounding area, including Farraline Park.Options include widening pavements, reducing traffic speeds and introducing streetscape features to improve the look and feel of the city centre.ldquoImproved links around the railway station, which is a key transport hub in the heart of the city, will be hugely welcomed by local businesses, said Mr Strachan who is chairman of the Inverness Business Improvement Districtand also chairman of Serco Caledonian Sleeper.ldquoReducing traffic speeds, increasing the width of footpaths and enhancing the streetscape by reducing the amount of redundant carriageway will all make the city centre more attractive for local residents and visitors alike.Mike Smith, Bid manager, said Academy Street was a main transport hub in the city.ldquoThat experience needs upgrading and this is a fantastic scheme to do that, he said.Dave Keane, community links manager for Sustrans Scotland, urged as many people as possible to get involved in this consultation process and use it as an opportunity to shape the future of Academy Street.ldquoThis project will also complement the wider improvements being made in Inverness through the Inverness City Active Travel Network project, he said.The Victorian Market located at the heart of the Accessing Inverness plan is in line for its own makeover in a separate project.Work will begin in January to improve the appearance of the Academy Street entrance to the complex which dates back to .It involves bringing the glazed screen closer to the street to improve visibility into the market. It will make the site more accessible, as well as improving security by reducing the number of access points in Academy Street to one.Lighting is set to be installed to highlight the buildingrsquos historic architecture and signage will be removed so it is more in keeping with the historic street faccedilade.The work marks the first stage of an action plan being implemented by the council and the Inverness Common Good Fund which will also see the remodelling of the market hall.Manager Jo Murray says the vision for Academy Street will bring further opportunities to increase footfall and spending.ldquoThis is a project that has great potential to benefit traders and shoppers through creating a more welcoming streetscape environment, with improved links to our railway station, bus station, shops and businesses, she said.Tuesday  Dec  : AM

title: Grooms wedding ring retuned after Belladrum field search
story: A METAL detectorist who combs the Belladrum Festival site for remnant tent pegs for refugees has discovered the camping ground is also a graveyard for lost wedding rings.Eric Soanefound two wedding rings during his annual scour and no fewer than eight couples have stepped forward to reclaim them, amongst them Michelle and Graham Robertson from Dumfries and Galloway who were ldquodelighted to be reunited with Grahamrsquos  carat white gold band lost mid-festival several years ago.Belladrum promoter Joe Gibb said: ldquoBelladrum is a popular wedding venue so we are really delighted that Eric has reunited Michelle with her husbandrsquos wedding ring.However, Mr Soane has not yet matched the other ring, a womanrsquos intricately-carved gold wedding band, to its rightful owner. The retired social worker hailed for finding the northrsquos biggest hoard of Roman coins at the festival site during his tent peg search several years ago, said he was whittling down responses.The pensioner, from Tornagrain, uses a high-quality metal detector to find as many tent pegs as he can for the Highland Supports Refugees charity, which has a major support base in Ross-shire.He spends weeks at a time rooting around the festival field with his high-quality American-made metal detector to find as many tent pegs as he can for the charity.Its volunteers also go around after the gig gathering up the abandoned tents, sleeping bags, welly boots and folding chairs to wash and transport to wherever they are needed.Last year, they started with Turkey and Chios in Greece, where volunteers said refugees first landed from dinghies.He also searches the playing fields of local schools to boost their coffers by handing back all the coins his machine detects.Primaries which have benefited from his efforts in the past include Kiltearn, Obsdale and Marybank.Tuesday  Dec  : AM

title: Innovative ideas are just the business at college
story: A THERAPEUTIC cow shoe, a bow stand to make archery accessible, and a sculptures from scrap metal business were among the winning ideas in a business competition.Ten out of  finalists shared in a prize fund of pound after pitching their ideas to a  of the regionrsquos top business and enterprise professionals.The University of the Highlands and Islandsrsquo Business Competition was run by Create, its centre for enterprise and innovation based at Inverness College UHI.The competition attrac-ted  entries, including  from students across the universityrsquos network.The top prize went to Stephenie Pagulayan, from Lerwick. Having been involved in community theatre for more than  years, she recently started her own social enterprise business, the Alice Theatre Project, after identying a lack of opportunities for young people to be creative in devising and performing theatre.She plans to expand her business where in Shetland and explore opportunities in Orkney.Other winners included Colin Cannon, from Dingwall, who won the best culture and environment business for his idea for a food and drink walking tour in Inverness. It would include local history, inspiring views and folklore, as well as local produce.ldquoTourists are always on the lookout for something intimate and memorable, he said.The best social impact business prize went to Stephanie Smith, from Inverness, for her idea of a charity called Leskills  Le, which would work with and support care-experienced young people, providing learning opportunities on topics like household management and maintenance, budget-ing and cooking.The charity would work alongside other agencies to cover topics of interest to young people like getting a job and staying healthy.Stephanie, who was in care until the age of , said: ldquoMost of these things people take for granted, but care-experienced young people have a need to learn these basic le skills but are leaving care ill-equipped.Neil Pirritt, from Culbokie, collected the best engineer award after coming up with the idea for the Bow Buddy, a free-standing, self-supported bow-stand, which would allow people with a physical disability to enjoy the sport of archery.The stand would be mobile and height adjustable to accommodate wheelchairs.College principal Prof-essor Chris OrsquoNeil said: ldquoEntrepreneurs and start-up innovation is critical to economic growth and job creation.ldquoUniversities and colleges have a signicant role to play in encouraging innovation and creativity within young people and at Inverness College UHI we try to embed the importance of these skills in their thinking so they move on and achieve their full potential.ldquoIt was wonderful to see such a range of exciting business ideas and I would like to personally wish every single finalist every success in their future endeavours.Tuesday  Dec  : AM

title: Massive drop in trade waste bins on streets
story: The number of bins now permanently littering Inverness city centre streets has been cut by  per cent since the introduction of a new trade waste policy last year.Councillors have hailed the policy as a great success after a massive reduction between February and August saw the numbers of bins drop from  to just  ndash back in  there were close to  bins ldquopermanently left out.The move has made the city centre more welcoming for the elderly and disabled who no longer have to negotiate their way past bins placed haphazardly about some of the cityrsquos busiest and most scenic streets.It also means that businesses are recycling more and are being more responsible with their waste which was one of the aims of the policy when it was brought in a year ago.The council launched an enforcement policy that saw traders issued with a total of  verbal warnings by officers and  formal warning letters were sent out while some bins were removed as it was not clear who owned them.The move has also won the support of the public and businesses with more than  per cent responding that the policy has reached its stated objectives of reducing bins cluttering pavements.One downside has been an increase in fly-tipping incidents in the city centre which saw environmental health officers issue two fixed penalty notices.Tuesday  Dec  : AM

title: Piping centre plan for Culloden site
story: The Highlands could have its first bagpipe centre near the scene of the Jacobite rout at Culloden in  that led to our national musical instrument being outlawed for years.Bagpipe makers Burgess Bagpipes have launched a crowdfunding campaign to raise pound, to start the first phase of the Highland Bagpipe Centre near Culloden Battlefield.Burgess Bagpipes is a Scottish family business who design and manufacture Scottish small pipes, Border pipes, and the Great Highland Bagpipe.Burgess Hay, his we Fiona and son Scott who run the business, are the only Highland bagpipe makers in the region.They transform blocks of African blackwood into high-quality instruments with a high degree of skill.Burgess said: ldquoOur family piping history dates back to the s. The skill, knowledge and experience wersquove obtained comes from an accumulation of an authentic Scottish ancestral mix of world champion players, skilled engineers, artists, tutors and judges.ldquoIt is usually a surprise when we tell people that there are three dferent types of Scottish Bagpipe used in Scotland today. They are amazed at how dferent they look and sound. We would like everyone that leaves the Highland Bagpipe Centre to be informed and inspired.ldquoIt will be a place to learn about how bagpipes are made, what they sound like and also how they are played.ldquoVisitors will have a fully immersive experience as we passionately share our history, tradition and culture.Jo Robinson, Visit Scotland regional director, said: ldquoThe centre would provide exactly the kind of high quality, authentic experience outlined in the national tourism strategy which lays out Scotlandrsquos collective ambition to be recognised as a destination of first choice. Visit Scotland commit to working closely with Burgess Bagpipes.The centre will include manufacturing , an archive, museum, exhibition and shop.The crowdfunding campaign runs until December . The online page can be found at https:www.crowdfunder highland-bagpipe-centreTuesday  Dec  : AM

title: Work starts on new homes in city centre
story: WORK has begun on a pound million development to create new affordable homes and commercial units at a derelict site in Inverness city centre.Over the next  months, a new five-storey building in Academy Street will replace the former Farm Foods supermarket currently being demolished.The project involves Highland Council, the Highland Housing Alliance, the Scottish Government and the Highland City Region Deal.It will comprise  one and two-bedroom flats of which  will be for rent from the council while the rest will be mid-market homes for the housing alliance. There will be four small commercial units on the ground floor.It will be named Wyvern House in tribute to the sitersquos history during the s and s when it was the premises of the SMT Vauxhall Garage and one of its best-selling models was the Wyvern car.Inverness Provost Helen Carmichael said it would create a new vibrancy in the area.ldquoAcademy Street is a historical gateway to the city centre and this project complements the work already underway to breathe new le into the area which has been crying out for regeneration and more homes, she said.Tuesday  Dec  : AM

title: dons captains praise for medics after seeing gms knocked out cold
story: Graeme Shinnie says seeing Gary Mackay-Steven being knocked out was the worst injury he has seen on a football pitch.And the Aberdeen captain also says seeing his stricken team-mate puts football in perspective.The Dons winger was involved in a nasty clash of heads with Celtic defender Dedryck Boyata in the th minute.Mackay-Steven had headed on Shay Logan‚Äôs cross and then clashed with Boyata as the Belgian tried to get to the ball first.The game was stopped for six minutes as the -year-old was treated by medical staff.Mackay-Steven was eventually stretchered off and taken to hospital with concussion, with Aberdeen confirming the winger has now been released after undergoing tests.He will certainly miss Wednesday#s Premiership clash with Rangers at Ibrox as he recovers.His skipper Shinnie was visibly upset in the moments after the collision and was gesturing for medical staff to hurry on to the pitch.In the aftermath of the incident, Shinnie said: ‚ÄúThese things happen in football and you have to deal with it.‚ÄúBut what happened to Gaz puts it in perspective a bit. It was a bad injury and it was not nice to see.‚ÄúThere‚Äôs more to itthan football and we wish Gaz all the best. The medics dealt with it really well.‚ÄúI was just hyped up seeing Gaz the way he was.‚ÄúIt was one of the worst I‚Äôve ever seen since I started playing football.‚ÄúI was just wanting to get things moving as quickly as possible and to get him the help he was needing.‚ÄúHe was out cold. He was knocked out but I don‚Äôt want to go into much more about what I saw out of respect for Gaz.‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt nice but the medics did really well to give him the help he needed.‚Äù
