title: help required to safeguard orkney native wildlife future
story: The Orkney public can play a pivotal role in protecting the county#s internationally important native wildle.An appeal is being made to landowners and homeowners across Mainland Orkney and the linked South Isles to help save the Orkney vole, hen harriers, short-eared owls and other ground nesting birds from the threat of stoats, and assist in getting an ambitious five-year project, designed to eradicate the non-native predator from the islands, off the ground.The ¬£. million Orkney Native Wildle Project will see over , trap boxes set out across Orkney, however, before this can take place, the project must gather permissions from landowners and homeowners.Speaking on behalf of the project, Bea Ayling said: ‚ÄúWe are appealing for land and homeowners to get in touch as soon as possible by emailing ONWP.LandAccess@gmail. At this time, we are looking to simply secure initial access permissions. Then, once the project team is in place next year, we will be in touch to discuss and agree bespoke access arrangements that are specic to each land holding.#Since being first recorded in the islands in , stoats can now be found throughout the county and pose a serious threat to Orkney#s unique native wildle.Alongside the trap boxes, biosecurity traps will be placed on other islands to prevent the spread of stoats, and in addition, the project, which will employ up to  full-time staff in  roles, will also see a team of skilled trappers and the UK#s first team of stoat detection dogs be employed.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: scout post ready for deliveries
story: The nd Orkney Scout Group will be running its traditional Scout Post starting today, Saturday, December .This is the major fundraiser for the group, ensuring the hall is able to be maintained and that all activities can be offered to members equally.The Scouts is looking for as much support as they can get this year in particular, as  will see the group celebrate its th birthday.The nd Orkney Scout Group have been in existence since , but due to the First World War weren‚Äôt officially recognised as a group until . According to leaders, it has been run continuously ever since ‚Äî the only group in Orkney to do so.This year, the card price is p¬†and boxes are delivered out into the town, this Saturday, December . Last collection will be Thursday, December .Deliveries will be made on the weekends of the December  and  and December  and , with all post due to be delivered by Christmas Eve.All mail will be distributed by the Beavers, Cubs and Scouts, and leaders have asked that you be kind and understanding with these young folk. Users of the post service are also requested to write as full an address as possible, as this will help greatly when sorting.And remember ‚Äî Scout Post can only be delivered within the Kirkwall town boundary. title: Alness High Street is the envy of the region
story: AN Easter Ross High Street is the ldquoenvy of other communities after it claimed a major national honour, a local MP believes.Jamie Stone said the success of Alness High Street in the Great British High Street awards shows just what can be achieved in towns with a strong community spirit.He was speaking after it won the champion high street award for Scotland.ldquoI am incredibly proud that Alness won the champion high street award and it is a real tribute to people like Councillor Carolyn Wilson and her team who put so much work in, said Mr Stone, whose constituency includes Easter Ross.ldquoAs someone who uses Alness High Street on a regular basis, I can vouch for just how vital it is. The iety and standard of the High Street businesses should be the envy of other communities.ldquoThank you to everyone who supported the team and voted for Alness high street, and thank you to those who worked so hard to achieve this recognition.Cllr Wilson, who runs Victoriana in Alness, believes the townrsquos success is due to the public spirit of the community, and praised the many volunteers who help to keep the town vibrant.She added: ldquoThe public got behind it and wersquove been overwhelmed by the support ndash not just in the local area but further afield as well. It really caught peoplersquos imaginations.That was certainly the case on social media, with an outpouring of praise online following the townrsquos award win.Ken Weir said: ldquoWell done Alness! Itrsquos great to see that itrsquos finally being recognised for the wonderful place it is! And Shona Sutherland added: ldquoWell deserved, always looks great!The town will be marking its success at a joint celebration and festive lights switch-on ceremony next Thursday.Shops will be opening later that night, offering a range of special deals. title: Ambulance service rejects claims about under manning
story: The Scottish Ambulance Service has denied that people are being put at risk because of alleged under-manning at two Easter Ross stations.A detailed letter sent to the Ross-shire Journal accuses the SAS of "ly" claiming both Alness and Tain stations are manned  .The letter states: ldquo There are shockingly y periods where either the Tain or Alness stations are closed leaving only one ambulance north of Dingwall to Wick.It claims delays in treatment and transport to hospital "are resulting in avoidable deaths and a future diminished quality of le for patients".It says lack of cover in Alness and Tain is having a massive knock on effect on Inverness and Dingwall ambulances, and that on a daily basis, ambulances from Inverness and Dingwall and beyond are sent to  calls in Easter Ross.Inverness has only two full-time ambulances and Dingwall one.It says response times in Easter Ross are being "patched up" with community first responders who are first aiders who cannot transport patients to hospital.The whistle-blower said that Golspie and Lairg stations work on an "on call" basis, adding "they are regularly closed due to crews being fatigued. Golspie is operational   three days a week."The writer states that the letter represents the feelings of paramedics and technicians in Easter Ross, and they are calling for six more staff to make Alness and Tain   and ldquogive the residents of Easter Ross a fighting chance in their hour of need".The Scottish Ambulance Service hit back however. A spokesman said: ldquoThe claims are untrue. We have ambulances working a   sht at Dingwall, Golspie, Lairg, Wick and Thurso ndash a crew is also available at either Tain or Alness stations and often both at the same time, depending on sht patterns.ldquoPatients in this part of Scotland can also rely on the air ambulance helicopter, a team of emergency response doctors based in Tain, Dornoch and Dingwall, and our teams of community first responders to provide an emergency response within a matter of minutes.ldquoWe closely and continuously monitor our staffing levels, through our demand and capacity review, to ensure we can provide safe patient care in all parts of Scotland and continue to invest in our workforce.Contacted for comment, Highlands and Islands Labour MSP Rhoda Grant said: ldquoStaff have raised concerns with me which I in turn have raised with the ambulance service. I believe that we do require more ambulance resources throughout the Highlands and Islands.ldquoCrews have to travel long distances to transfer patients and with specialist services becoming more centralised that will only increase.ldquoIt is right that crews who are fatigued sign off and ideally we should have more stations covered without the use of on call staff, who are in greater danger of becoming fatiguedthey have already undertaken a long transfer.ldquoI know from SAS that they are using Inverness crews to do some of these transfers where that is clinically safe.ldquoObviously in an emergency the nearest crew must respond. Sadly the whole of our public sector is suffering from the impact of funding cuts and we must now end austerity and fund the le line services that our people need.Share your views by emailing us at newsdesk@spp-groupTuesday  Dec  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Avoch housing plan gets the nod
story: NEW social housing in a Black Isle village will be a big boost to residents eager to find affordable local accommodation, a councillor has said.Black Isle ward member Cllr Craig Fraser was speaking after the North Planning Applications Committee approved plans for  homes in Avoch.A number of residents and the local community council had raised concerns over the plans for the site at Memorial Field in Station Road ndash citing the height of some of the buildings in an elevated spot, concerns over additional traffic and the impact of the scheme on local drainage.However, Cairn Housing Associationrsquos proposals were recommended for approval by Highland Council planning officers, and voted through by the committeelast week.The new estate will feature  three-bedroom homes, two four-bedroom houses, six two-bedroom bungalows and a further eight one-bedroom flats within two blocks.Cllr Fraser welcomed the development, citing a need for social housing for local residents.He also praised a condition extending the villagersquos mph limit out past the development, and another requiring the creation of a play park within the estate. There will also be cash for local education provision.ldquoThere is much to welcome in this development as it will be built along the same lines as the affordable properties in Munlochy and Culbokie, he said.But he added there were legitimate local concerns over a number of factors, including rising traffic levels on the A, and that in future he wished to see ldquothe concerns of the community council and Avoch residents taken seriously, by way of increased dialogue with the Highland Council planning officers, applicant, community council and Avoch residents.Tuesday  Dec  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Black Isle reverends Corsa is on its bike at last
story: A PEDAL-POWERED Vauxhall Corsa has finally found a new home after its church minister owners slung it on eBay when they realised it was torture to pedal uphill - despite it being able to be powered by all four of its occupants at the same time.The future looked bleak for the lime green four-seater after husband and we team James Bissett and Susan Cord rendered it surplus to requirements.The thrill-seeking duo bought it off eBay for pound with big plans to use it to get round the North Coast  on a fundraising road run taking a leaf out of The Flintstones book.But the plan was axed when they realised it was too heavy to peddle uphill.And now, three months after popping it back on eBay a buyer has whisked it off to Manchester in the back of a Luton box van.Bike enthusiast Pete Abel said he had plans to use it as a star attraction in the citys annual Manchester Day Parade, all going well.He said: "Its a celebration of Manchester and the community groups that make up the city and everything used has to either be peddled or pushed. title: Blow for Dingwall as salmon factory to close by the end of the year
story: A ROSS-shire town left reeling by the impending loss of more than  jobs in the run-up to Christmas is gearing up to fight back against the devastating blow.Confirmation that the Edinburgh Salmon Company is to close its fish processing plant in Dingwall by the end of the year was branded "a huge blow", with  staff and up to  agency workers left looking for work.Local Citizens Advice Bureau staff have already been working with those affected by the closure announced by plant owners Europeacuteenne de la Mer, a subsidiary of the Thai Union Group, in a bid to find out how they can help.Meanwhile Dingwall is next Fridayset to try and mitigate the blow by staging a jobs fair which has been rapidly put together by MP Ian Blackford and MSP Kate Forbes, politicians who have constituency offices in the town.Dingwall and Seaforth ward councillor Graham Mackenzie said the news was still sinking in.He said: "This is devastating news. Its going to have a big impact. People now realise itrsquos not just the employees that are going to be affected, itrsquos all their friends and families as well as many local businesses."And its not just Dingwall where this will be felt. I have been told that people are coming from all over and from as far away as Ullapool to work there."This was echoed by fellow ward councillor Angela MacLean. She said: "This is extremely sad news for all the staff who have been loyal employees of the Edinburgh Salmon Company for many years. The business has had a long association with Dingwall and this closure will have a knock-on effect on many of the local businesses in the area."There is never a good time to be made redundant but in the run up to Christmas this is a double blow for many local families.MSP John Finne said: "This is bitterly disappointing news from the Edinburgh Salmon Company, and will come as a blow to all those workers on site. I have sought assurances that the Scottish Government will continue to make every possible effort to assist the workforce of Edinburgh Salmon Company in light of this closure."There are fears that some families of Eastern European origin who have contributed to the local economy for upwards of a decade are now considering cutting their losses and leaving the area."I know because of this loads of people will go back to Poland," said a Polish national who has friends working there. "Its going to be a dficult time for those people. Some of them have worked there for  years."Another member of the Polish community, who also did not want to be named, said: "My partner used to work there. I feel sorry for my friends and their families. I know how people are feeling, but nobody will speak about it. There are loads of people working there and people are scared."In a statement, Europeacuteenne de la Mer, which has cited challenging market conditions and is understood to have registered losses in excess of poundmillion, said it regretted "no feasible alternative solution to closure was found during collective consultation" and the factory will close at the end of the year. It will meet its obligations until the turn of the year when the factory will close.It said: "We would like to thank all employees for their commitment to the company to date and their professionalism during this dficult time."Next Fridays jobs fair in Dingwall will run from pm to pm at the Town hall. MP Ian Blackford said: "Dingwall and the surrounding areas have many opportunities waiting to be explored let us all work together to make these readily available to the people who live and work here."Tuesday  Dec  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. story: A THERAPEUTIC cow shoe, a bow stand to make archery accessible, and sculptures from a scrap metal business were among the winning ideas in a business competition.Ten out of  finalists shared in a prize fund of pound after pitching their ideas to a  of the regionrsquos top business and enterprise professionals.The University of the Highlands and Islandsrsquo Business Competition was run by Create, its centre for enterprise and innovation based at Inverness College UHI.The competition attracted  entries, including  from students across the universityrsquos network.The top prize went to Stephenie Pagulayan, from Lerwick. title: Just the ticket for tackling debt
story: Scottish Government ViewpointTHE Scottish Government has launched a People, Not Profit campaign to support the Scottish Credit Unions that play a vital role in helping people stay out of unmanageable debt.The campaign seeks to support the growth of the sector by raising awareness of credit unions and the services they offer to a wider and more erse audience.Aileen Campbell, Cabinet Secretary for Communities and Local Government, launched the campaign.A new survey has revealed one in five Scots have not heard of a credit union.Currently, around , people across the country are part of a credit union some seven per cent of the population.The survey revealed also that only two-fthsof people questioned thought they would be eligible to be a member of a credit union, and that one in four peoplewrongly believe they make profits for shareholders, just like banks.The campaign will highlight credit unions are not-for-profit organisations providing loans and savings, and most people would be eligible to join at least one credit union based on where they work or where they live.A new website has been launched to help people find out which credit union they could be a member of.Ms Campbell said: "In helping build a fairer Scotland, we want to protect people from getting into unmanageable debt and falling into the hands of predatory, high-cost lenders."A key part of this is making sure that people are aware of the financial services and fair alternatives available, including credit union membership."Our new campaign will highlight the benefits of joining a credit union and I would encourage everyone to visit the new website to find out more."Michael Sheen, actor and social activist, who is a credit union member, has worked with the Scottish Government to produce a short video explaining what the organisations are.* For more information, visit www.creditunions.scotTuesday  Dec  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Pictures give glimpse of life behind the lines
story: A PERFORMANCE of songs from the trenches next week promises to be particularly poignant for one of the singers taking part.Photographs straight from her fascinating familys album will be projected behind Dingwall and District Choral Society during its Lest We Forget ndash A Commemoration in Word, Song and Pictures at Strathpeffer Pavilion next Friday.Jenny Raymond, who lives in Brahan, was the first person in  years to lay eyes on the war diaries of her grandfather, Fred Proudfoot, offering a glimpse of le during his stint with the Black Watch in World War I. His Box Brownie photographs shed a fascinating light on le at that time.She was drawn also to stories about her grandmother, Jessie Proudfoot, who lost three brothers ndash John, Francis and David Buchan ndash in the conflict. John was posthumously awarded the Victoria Cross.Growing up, she was aware of old suitcases filled with photographs, diaries and memories that spoke to her love of history. She said: "As kids we would take them out from time to time, maybe not realising their true signicance."My father, also named Frederick after his Dad, told us his father never talked of the war in any serious way. Suffice to say on one occasion he had the ominous job of protecting the only  record that the platoon had ndash after any battle that was the first thing that had to be undamaged."Struggling to read the minute handwriting in her grandfathers diaries, she nevertheless persevered after her fathers death, feeling she owed it to him. She said: "Most of all it was important to the memory of my grandfather that his diaries were not lost. They were fading but with modern scanning Ive been able to slowly scan photos and work through the diaries. Once I started I have been captivated by what I have seen and read. I hope to produce a book of these memories for my family."It has been an emotional roller-coaster reading the diaries and I am transported into the mind of my grandfather, a man I never knew. In his writing and thoughts he is so like my father who I miss very much. I am honoured to be the first person who has read these diaries in  years."The performance takes place at Strathpeffer Pavilion on Friday, December  at .pm.
